Award.AwardTitle: WORKSHOP: Workshop on Ethical Challenges of Experiments in the Social Sciences

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
This workshop at the University of California San Diego brings together an international group of scholars from several social science disciplines, representatives of institutional review boards, and professionals from the research support and publication communities to address ethical issues emerging in the design and implementation of experimental research. The workshop focuses on identifying the central ethical issues, establishing clear guidelines, and working toward a consensus in the field to protect the integrity of research.

The intellectual merit of the project is associated with its attention to a growing approach to scientific inquiry across the social sciences. Scholars have increasingly employed field, laboratory, and survey experiments both inside and outside the United States to evaluate a range of theoretically-driven questions. While obtaining clearance from US-based IRBs is a regular requirement, standards do not exist for obtaining similar approvals from the countries hosting the research activities. The workshop will address the ethical, intellectual, and scholarly issues in conducting experimental work outside the United States.

The workshop's broader impacts are connected with its goal of developing recommendations for researchers across the social sciences. The workshop will involve a range of experts who will publish the findings and recommendations, making them available to the scholarly community, professional associations, and the public.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project examined the emerging ethical challenges facing social science research and proposed solutions that will protect subjects, scholars, and the research enterprise. Over the last 20 years, there has been a dramatic increase in the use of experiments by political scientists. However, existing human subjects' rules are largely designed for biomedical research and do not offer guidance for some of the difficult problems confronting faculty. For example,  field experiments may treat hundreds of thousands of subjects without any informed consent, and theoretically could affect election outcomes. They are generally legal - but are they ethical? Another common situation involves conducting experiments overseas where foreign governments may have difficult or corrupt rules governing research. How does one proceed when a foreign ethics committee requests a bribe? These are new questions and scholars are unsure how to proceed. This project organized a conference of leading scholars to identify, discuss, and debate the most critical issues. The project also funded a survey of scholars and of citizens to understand opinions about these types of experiments. The results to date include a book on ethics of social science experiments, a number of other publications, and important steps toward revising the American Political Science Association's professional ethics guidelines.
